articles.headline: White-Collar Companies Race to Be Last to Return to the Office
articles.snippet: Google, Facebook, Amazon, Capital One and others are extending work-from-home policies to September and sometimes far beyond.
articles.abstract: Google, Facebook, Amazon, Capital One and others are extending work-from-home policies to September and sometimes far beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as President Trump has said “we have to get our country open again,” much of corporate America is in no rush to return employees to their campuses and skyscrapers. The companies are racing not to be the first back, but the last.

articles.headline: In Flynn Case, Barr Again Takes Aim at Mueller Inquiry
articles.snippet: The Justice Department’s move was the latest example of the attorney general’s effort to chisel away at the special counsel investigation and emphasize an alternate narrative.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department’s move was the latest example of the attorney general’s effort to chisel away at the special counsel investigation and emphasize an alternate narrative.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after admitting guilt to a federal judge in December 2017 for lying to the F.B.I., Michael T. Flynn issued a statement saying what he did was wrong, and “through my faith in God, I am working to set things right.”

articles.headline: Two White House Coronavirus Cases Raise Question of if Anyone Is Really Safe
articles.snippet: If it is so hard to maintain a healthy environment at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, then how can businesses across the country establish a safe space for their workers?
articles.abstract: If it is so hard to maintain a healthy environment at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, then how can businesses across the country establish a safe space for their workers?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his eagerness to reopen the country, President Trump faces the challenge of convincing Americans that it would be safe to go back to the workplace. But the past few days have demonstrated that even his own workplace may not be safe from the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: Georgia Killing Puts Spotlight on a Police Force’s Troubled History
articles.snippet: The shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery has renewed criticism of the police agency that released the two suspects. They were charged by the state months later.
articles.abstract: The shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery has renewed criticism of the police agency that released the two suspects. They were charged by the state months later.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — When the Glynn County Police Department arrived at the scene of a fatal shooting in February in southeastern Georgia, officers encountered a former colleague with the victim’s blood on his hands.
articles.byline: By Rick Rojas, Richard Fausset and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Fight Over Virus’s Death Toll Opens Grim New Front in Election Battle
articles.snippet: Elements of the right have sought to bolster President Trump’s political standing by turning scientific questions into political issues.
articles.abstract: Elements of the right have sought to bolster President Trump’s political standing by turning scientific questions into political issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: The claim was tailor-made for President Trump’s most steadfast backers: Federal guidelines are coaching doctors to mark Covid-19 as the cause of death even when it is not, inflating the pandemic’s death toll.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: There’s Money Stuck in Your Dependent Care Account. Now What?
articles.snippet: After-school programs are closed. Day care centers are shut down. Summer camp might not happen. If you’re stuck with money you can’t use, you’ll lose it.
articles.abstract: After-school programs are closed. Day care centers are shut down. Summer camp might not happen. If you’re stuck with money you can’t use, you’ll lose it.
articles.lead_paragraph: You did everything right. You read the email from human resources and signed up for a dependent care account. Your employer siphons pretax money from your paycheck, and you’ll get a little back upon request after paying each day care bill, or in a lump sum after covering summer camp costs.

articles.headline: As Job Losses Mount, Lawmakers Face a Make-or-Break Moment
articles.snippet: The United States just lost 20 million jobs. The wrong federal response could make those layoffs a permanent fixture of the U.S. economy and sentence thousands of companies to bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: The United States just lost 20 million jobs. The wrong federal response could make those layoffs a permanent fixture of the U.S. economy and sentence thousands of companies to bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the nation confronts unemployment levels not seen since the Great Depression, Congress and the Trump administration face a pivotal choice: Continue spending trillions trying to shore up businesses and workers, or bet that state reopenings will jump-start the United States economy.

articles.headline: The Grapelord of Napa Faces a Threat Worse Than Plague
articles.snippet: For 50 years, Andy Beckstoffer drove up the price of wine. Did the strategy work too well?
articles.abstract: For 50 years, Andy Beckstoffer drove up the price of wine. Did the strategy work too well?
articles.lead_paragraph: One balmy winter afternoon, Andy Beckstoffer, a grape grower who has done more than nearly anyone to shape the premium U.S. wine industry, was sitting in Mustard’s, a restaurant in Napa Valley that is a kind of clubhouse for the vintner class. Although Beckstoffer Vineyards, the largest private grower in California, had recently set a sales record with a blockbuster harvest of $55 million worth of cabernet sauvignon, its founder was not in the mood to celebrate. The wine industry was in trouble, facing its worst outlook in generations — and that was before the coronavirus struck.

articles.headline: For Flynn, Dropped Charges Are the Latest in a Life Full of Reversals
articles.snippet: For most of his life, Michael Flynn has swung from being “a good soldier” to an agent of disruption.
articles.abstract: For most of his life, Michael Flynn has swung from being “a good soldier” to an agent of disruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There have always been two sides to Michael T. Flynn. There was the rebellious teenager who surfed during hurricanes and spent a night in juvenile reformatory. Then there was the adult who buckled down, joined the Army and rose to become a three-star general.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Pork Chops vs. People: Battling Coronavirus in an Iowa Meat Plant
articles.snippet: After President Trump’s executive order, meat plants are reopening. Can they do so without endangering their low-wage workers and their communities?
articles.abstract: After President Trump’s executive order, meat plants are reopening. Can they do so without endangering their low-wage workers and their communities?
articles.lead_paragraph: On April 10, Tony Thompson, the sheriff for Black Hawk County in Iowa, visited the giant Tyson Foods pork plant in Waterloo. What he saw, he said, “shook me to the core.”
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Questions of Bias in Covid-19 Treatment Add to the Mourning for Black Families
articles.snippet: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have advised health professionals to be on the lookout for medical bias.
articles.abstract: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have advised health professionals to be on the lookout for medical bias.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long dissatisfied with the doctor treating his diabetes, Reginald Relf decided to fight through whatever was causing his nagging cough. But then his temperature spiked and his breathing became so labored that he reluctantly took his sister’s advice to visit a doctor.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Audra D. S. Burch

articles.headline: As Europe Reopens Schools, Relief Combines With Risk
articles.snippet: Restarting classes is central to reviving economies. But one question haunts the efforts: Just how contagious are children, and could they be the next super spreaders?
articles.abstract: Restarting classes is central to reviving economies. But one question haunts the efforts: Just how contagious are children, and could they be the next super spreaders?
articles.lead_paragraph: NEUSTRELITZ, Germany — It was Lea Hammermeister’s first day back at school after almost two months at home and she was already preparing for a test.

articles.headline: From Coffee Filter to Safety Mask, in a Hurry
articles.snippet: Melitta, the German maker of the original paper coffee filter, retooled its production to make masks. A director called the filter’s perfect fit over the face “a gift from heaven.”
articles.abstract: Melitta, the German maker of the original paper coffee filter, retooled its production to make masks. A director called the filter’s perfect fit over the face “a gift from heaven.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As the wave of coronavirus infections broke over Europe in March, causing reserves of medical supplies to disappear, German authorities made a nationwide appeal: More safety masks were urgently needed.

articles.headline: The Airline Business Is Terrible. It Will Probably Get Even Worse.
articles.snippet: An industry that is intimately familiar with failure confronts a crisis unlike any other. Executives say they have no idea when passengers will return.
articles.abstract: An industry that is intimately familiar with failure confronts a crisis unlike any other. Executives say they have no idea when passengers will return.
articles.lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines started 2020 celebrating what it said was the most successful year in company history. Not long after, it shared a record $1.6 billion in profits with its 90,000 employees. But with air travel nearly shut down by the coronavirus, the airline is now bleeding money and will drop 10 more airports from its already skeletal network on Wednesday.

articles.headline: Big Tech Has Crushed the News Business. That’s About to Change.
articles.snippet: News organizations have long hoped that tech platforms would pay them for news. Now regulators abroad are moving to make that happen.
articles.abstract: News organizations have long hoped that tech platforms would pay them for news. Now regulators abroad are moving to make that happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: It reads like a coroner’s report on the news business, 623 pages filled with charts and graphs detailing the devastating decline in local news and public policy reporting of the past decade. It landed on the Australian prime minister’s desk last summer, unnoticed by most news consumers in America and around the world.

articles.headline: Joe Biden’s Time in Sarah Palin’s Shadow
articles.snippet: What two strange months in 2008 taught the former vice president about the politics of grievance, and how that might help him pick a running mate of his own to take on Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: What two strange months in 2008 taught the former vice president about the politics of grievance, and how that might help him pick a running mate of his own to take on Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joe Biden was getting the hang of being overshadowed. It was not a bad life.

articles.headline: How Do You Enforce a Law That Tramples the Land of the Free?
articles.snippet: Angela Alvarado, a veteran prosecutor in the Santa Clara district attorney’s office in California, has to weigh safety, freedom and the law as she fields complaints about stay-at-home violations.
articles.abstract: Angela Alvarado, a veteran prosecutor in the Santa Clara district attorney’s office in California, has to weigh safety, freedom and the law as she fields complaints about stay-at-home violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ALTOS, Calif. — A veteran prosecutor in Northern California has turned her kitchen table into an improvised command post where she is enforcing Santa Clara County’s strict lockdown order.
articles.byline: By Katey Rusch and Casey Smith

articles.headline: Employers Rush to Adopt Virus Screening. The Tools May Not Help Much.
articles.snippet: Symptom-checking apps and fever-screening cameras promise to keep sick workers at home and hinder the virus. But experts warn they can be inaccurate and violate privacy.
articles.abstract: Symptom-checking apps and fever-screening cameras promise to keep sick workers at home and hinder the virus. But experts warn they can be inaccurate and violate privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bob Grewal recently began testing a new health-screening setup for workers at a Subway restaurant he owns in Los Angeles near the University of Southern California.

articles.headline: As Banks Stumble in Delivering Aid, Congress Weighs Other Options
articles.snippet: Accounts provided by the Federal Reserve and distributions handled by payroll processors are among the ideas floating around Capitol Hill.
articles.abstract: Accounts provided by the Federal Reserve and distributions handled by payroll processors are among the ideas floating around Capitol Hill.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the federal government agreed to funnel $2.2 trillion in emergency aid to Americans devastated by the economic shutdown, the nation’s banks were given a central role.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: China Is Defensive. The U.S. Is Absent. Can the Rest of the World Fill the Void?
articles.snippet: Smaller countries like Australia are trying to build a new kind of alliance, by first investigating what went wrong in the early stages of the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.abstract: Smaller countries like Australia are trying to build a new kind of alliance, by first investigating what went wrong in the early stages of the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — When Australia started pushing for a global inquiry into the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, no other countries were on board, and officials had no idea how it would work or how harshly China might react.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Isabella Kwai
